body.p: In the last part, I introduced some mdoc language syntax by way of example. In this part, I'll study the structure of the UNIX manual itself.

The syntax and structure of mdoc are closely tied to roff, a text processing language predating the first editions of UNIX. In fact, the general syntax of mdoc can be traced to the RUNOFF utility developed in 1964 by Jerome H. Saltzer for the CTSS operating system.

blockquote.p: Input generally consists of English text, 360 or fewer characters to a line. Control words must begin a new line, and begin with a period so that they may be distinguished from other text. RUNOFF does not print the control words.

body.p: The conventions of section names and manual categories were later formalised in the UNIX Programmer's Manual for the First Edition UNIX, 1971.

I reiterate that this is not a canonical mdoc reference: mdoc is not a standard, and varies in subtle ways across formatters and operating systems. In this part, I'll discuss only the portable parts of mdoc.
